pages.text: Hepatizon (Greek etymology: "liver"), also known as Black Corinthian $(l:materials/Bronze)Bronze$(/l), was a highly valuable metal alloy in classical antiquity. It is thought to be an alloy of $(l:materials/Copper)copper$(/l) with the addition of a small proportion of $(l:materials/Gold)gold$(/l) and $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) (perhaps as little as 8% of each), mixed and treated to produce a material with a dark purplish patina, similar to the colour of liver. It is referred to in various ancient texts, but few known examples of

hepatizon exist today.Of the known types of $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l) or $(l:materials/Brass)brass$(/l) in classical antiquity, hepatizon was the second most valuable. Pliny the Elder mentions it in his Natural History, stating that it is less valuable than Corinthian $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l), which contained a greater proportion of $(l:materials/Gold)gold$(/l) or $(l:materials/Silver)silver$(/l) and as a result resembled the precious metals, but was esteemed before $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l) from Delos and Aegina. As a result of its dark colour, it was particularly
valued for statues. According to Pliny, the method of making it, like that for Corinthian $(l:materials/Bronze)bronze$(/l), had been lost for a long time.
